title: Behavioral Signals in Crypto: Analyzing Sentiment and Search Trends as Predictors of Market Volatility
text:
1 Introduction
This project examines how behavioral factors such as sentiment and attention shape cryptocurrency market dynamics between October 2024 and October 2025, focusing on Bitcoin and Ethereum. Motivated by my background in neuroscience and my interest in transitioning to finance, I am particularly drawn to understanding how patterns of human behavior manifest in financial data. Cryptocurrencies provide an ideal setting for this research because their prices are highly sensitive to collective mood and information flow, often reacting to changes in public sentiment and online search activity quite rapidly. The analysis centers on three questions: How daily sentiment fluctuations, whether optimistic or pessimistic, correlate with market volatility and returns, whether spikes in public attention, measured through Google search interest, precede or follow periods of heightened instability, and whether Bitcoin and Ethereum differ in how strongly they respond to these behavioral signals. Through these questions, the project aims to understand how behavioral and psychological dynamics influence financial market movements.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
This project integrates three open data sources to examine how market activity, online sentiment, and public attention evolve for Bitcoin and Ethereum between December 2, 2024 and December 1, 2025. This one year window corresponds to the maximum period available under the free tiers of the APIs used in this project: both CoinGecko and Santiment restrict historical access to approximately the past 365 days unless a paid plan is used.
Daily market data come from the CoinGecko Market Data API, which compiles cryptocurrency prices, trading volumes, and market capitalization across major global exchanges. Online sentiment is obtained from the Santiment API, which analyzes social media discussions and other text based signals to estimate the overall tone toward each asset. Public attention is measured using Google Trends, accessed through the gtrendsR package in R, which provides normalized daily search interest for the keywords “bitcoin” and “ethereum.”
API requests require authentication, so all keys were stored privately in my .Renviron file. The data pull script automatically downloads the raw JSON responses, converts them into CSV files, and stores them in data/raw/. These raw files are then cleaned, standardized, and merged by coin and date. This includes aligning timestamps to a daily frequency, normalizing sentiment values, and handling a small number of missing days, primarily dates where Santiment did not report sentiment data, which is common due to API rate limits or gaps in social media coverage.
The final merged dataset contains one full year of daily observations for each coin and provides a reproducible foundation for exploring how market conditions, sentiment, and search behavior relate to cryptocurrency volatility.
All data collection and preprocessing steps are contained in 1 Data Pull.qmd, which downloads data from all three APIs, saves raw files to data/raw/, and writes the cleaned, merged dataset to data/clean/merged_crypto_sentiment_trends.csv.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1.1 Data Sources
CoinGecko Market Data API:
https://www.coingecko.com/en/api
Santiment API:
https://api.santiment.net
Google Trends via gtrendsR:
(Daily search interest for “bitcoin” and “ethereum”)


2.1.2 Data Dictionary
Below are the variables included in the final cleaned dataset, along with their scales and how to interpret them.

date
Daily timestamp for each observation, used to align all behavioral and market indicators.
coin
Asset identifier ("BITCOIN" or "ETHEREUM"), allowing comparison across the two markets.
price
Daily closing price in USD. Interpreted directly in dollars to track overall price levels and trends.
volume
Total trading volume for the day, measured in units traded. Higher values indicate more active trading.
market_cap
Total market value in USD, reflecting the size and economic weight of each asset.
sentiment_score
Daily sentiment index ranging roughly from −0.1 to 0.1. Higher values indicate more optimistic discussion.
Source: Derived from text sentiment API scores averaged by day.
search_interest
Google Trends search index between 0 and 100. Higher values represent greater public attention.
Source: Directly from Google Trends API.
daily_return
Day over day percentage price change, typically between -0.1 and 0.1. Measures short term market movement.
Calculation: daily_return_t = (price_t - price_{t-1}) / price_{t-1}
volatility_7d
Seven day rolling standard deviation of daily returns, used to capture short term variability.
Calculation: volatility_7d_t = sd(daily_return_{t-6}, ..., daily_return_t)

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis
The goal of this section is to describe where these gaps occur, whether they follow meaningful patterns, and how they should be handled prior to analysis.

2.2.1 Missingness Summary


Code
#| message: false
#| warning: false

# Load all libraries silently
suppressPackageStartupMessages({
  library(tidyverse)
  library(naniar)
  library(janitor)
  library(here)
  library(scales)
  library(zoo)
  library(patchwork)
  library(knitr)
  library(kableExtra)
})

df <- read_csv(here("data", "clean", "merged_crypto_sentiment_trends.csv"), show_col_types = FALSE) |>
  janitor::clean_names()




Code
df |>
  summarise(across(everything(), ~ sum(is.na(.)))) |>
  pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "variable", values_to = "missing_count") |>
  arrange(desc(missing_count))


To compare missingness across variables, the plot below shows the percentage of missing values for each variable within each coin.


Code
nice_names <- c(
  daily_return    = "Daily Return",
  date            = "Date",
  market_cap      = "Market Cap",
  price           = "Price",
  search_interest = "Search Interest",
  sentiment_score = "Sentiment Score",
  volatility_7d   = "7-Day Volatility",
  volume          = "Volume",
  coin            = "Coin"
)

miss_coin <- df |>
  mutate(across(everything(), ~ is.na(.), .names = "miss_{col}")) |>
  group_by(coin) |>
  summarise(across(starts_with("miss_"), mean)) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("miss_"),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "missing_prop"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    missing_pct = missing_prop * 100,
    variable = str_remove(variable, "miss_"),
    variable = nice_names[variable]
  )

# ggplot(miss_coin, aes(x = fct_reorder(variable, missing_pct), y = missing_pct)) +
#   geom_col(fill = "#3182bd") +
#   facet_grid(
#     rows = vars(coin),
#     scales = "free_x",
#     switch = "x"
#   ) +
#   labs(
#     x = NULL,
#     y = "Percent Missing",
#     title = "Missingness by Coin"
#   ) +
#   scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent(scale = 1)) +
#   theme_grey(base_size = 16) +
#   theme(
#     strip.placement = "outside",
#     strip.text = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
#     axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 12),
#     axis.text.y = element_text(size = 12)
#   )


df |>
  group_by(coin) |>
  summarise(
    `Sentiment Score` = mean(is.na(sentiment_score)) * 100,
    `Search Interest` = mean(is.na(search_interest)) * 100,
    `Daily Return` = mean(is.na(daily_return)) * 100,
    `7-Day Volatility` = mean(is.na(volatility_7d)) * 100,
    Price = mean(is.na(price)) * 100,
    Volume = mean(is.na(volume)) * 100
  ) |>
  pivot_longer(-coin, names_to = "Variable", values_to = "pct") |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = coin, values_from = pct) |>
  arrange(desc(BITCOIN)) |>
  kable(
    digits = 1,
    col.names = c("Variable", "Bitcoin (%)", "Ethereum (%)")
  ) |>
  kable_styling(
    bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"),
    full_width = FALSE,
    font_size = 16
  ) |>
  row_spec(0, bold = TRUE, color = "white", background = "#3182bd")





Variable

The plot shows that missingness is concentrated in variables that rely on external data sources rather than market feeds. Sentiment Score has the highest proportion of missing values, close to 8.5 % for both Bitcoin and Ethereum. Search Interest and 7 Day Volatility follow with smaller gaps of about 1.6 and 1.9 %. Daily Return has roughly 0.3 % missingness, which corresponds to the initial day of each series when no previous price exists. The core market variables Coin, Date, Price, Volume, and Market Cap are fully observed across the entire year. Bitcoin and Ethereum display almost identical missingness patterns, which indicates that the gaps come from shared upstream sources rather than asset specific issues.



2.2.2 Missingness Over Time
Understanding how missingness evolves over time provides insight into whether gaps are random or structured. The analysis next focuses on the four variables with missing values to identify the timing and potential causes of these gaps.


Code
vars_with_missing <- c(
  "sentiment_score",
  "search_interest",
  "volatility_7d",
  "daily_return"
)

df_long <- df |>
  select(date, coin, all_of(vars_with_missing)) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = all_of(vars_with_missing),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "value"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    missing = is.na(value),
    variable = recode(variable,
      sentiment_score = "Sentiment Score",
      search_interest = "Search Interest",
      volatility_7d   = "7-Day Volatility",
      daily_return    = "Daily Return"
    )
  ) |>
  filter(missing)

ggplot(df_long, aes(x = date, y = variable)) +
  geom_point(color = "#e6550d", size = 3) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 1) +
  labs(
    x = "Date",
    y = "Variable",
    title = "Missingness Over Time by Variable"
  ) +
  theme_grey(base_size = 16)









Missingness occurs in well defined locations rather than at random. Sentiment Score and Search Interest share identical missing dates late in the year for both coins, which points to temporary gaps in the external data sources rather than issues with the market data itself. Daily Return is missing only on the first available date, where it cannot be computed, and 7-Day Volatility is missing during the first six days of each series due to the rolling window requirement.



2.2.3 Price Behavior on Missing vs. Non-Missing Days
Since the gaps for sentiment score and search interest originate from upstream data limitations, the next step is to determine whether imputation is appropriate. Given that the dataset covers only one year for each asset, retaining as many observations as possible is valuable. However, imputation should only be applied if missingness is unrelated to unusual market conditions. For this reason, I examine whether missingness in the externally sourced variables aligns with abnormal price behavior before deciding how to proceed.


Code
p1 <- df |>
  mutate(sent_missing = if_else(is.na(sentiment_score), "Missing", "Present")) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = sent_missing, y = price)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#3182bd", alpha = 0.45, color = "black", linewidth = 0.7) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 2, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(x = "Sentiment Score Status", y = "Price") +
  theme_grey(base_size = 14)

p2 <- df |>
  mutate(search_missing = if_else(is.na(search_interest), "Missing", "Present")) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = search_missing, y = price)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#3182bd", alpha = 0.45, color = "black", linewidth = 0.7) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 2, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(x = "Search Interest Status", y = "Price") +
  theme_grey(base_size = 14)

p1 / p2 + 
  plot_annotation(title = "Price Levels on Days With and Without Missing Values")









Sentiment Score: Price levels look similar on days with and without missing sentiment, with overlapping medians and interquartile ranges. This suggests that missingness in sentiment does not correspond to unusual market conditions. The gaps likely reflect coverage issues in the sentiment feed rather than price movements.
Search Interest: Price distributions again overlap closely, indicating that missing search interest values are not linked to abnormal price behavior. Google Trends often omits low volume days or returns incomplete windows, and the pattern here aligns with those expected limitations.


2.2.4 Imputation Strategy
Linear interpolation is used only for Sentiment Score and Search Interest, since their missing values come from gaps in the external APIs rather than from anything inherent to the data. In contrast, the early missing values in Daily Return and 7-Day Volatility are expected, because these metrics cannot be computed at the start of the series, so those NA values are left in place. This strikes a balance between preserving the meaning of the derived variables and smoothing the two externally sourced features. Because the dataset is fairly small (one year per coin), filling these external gaps also helps avoid unnecessarily losing observations, even though the overall amount of missingness is low.


Code
df_imputed <- df |>
  arrange(coin, date) |>
  group_by(coin) |>
  mutate(
    sentiment_score_imp = na.approx(sentiment_score, na.rm = FALSE),
    search_interest_imp = na.approx(search_interest, na.rm = FALSE),
    daily_return_imp    = daily_return,
    volatility_7d_imp   = volatility_7d
  ) |>
  ungroup()

df_imputed |>
  summarize(
    sentiment_original_NA = sum(is.na(sentiment_score)),
    sentiment_filled_NA   = sum(is.na(sentiment_score_imp)),
    search_original_NA    = sum(is.na(search_interest)),
    search_filled_NA      = sum(is.na(search_interest_imp))
  )




2.2.5 Outlier Detection
It is also useful to check for unusually large or extreme observations. Because the variables in this dataset operate on very different scales, some extreme points may not be obvious at first glance. Looking for outliers helps confirm that the data behave as expected during periods of high market activity and ensures that no unexpected spikes are the result of data errors. This step provides an additional check on data quality before moving into the exploratory analysis.
Variables vary widely in scale, so outlier detection uses standardized Z-scores. This produces a comparable frame of reference and highlights unusually large deviations.


Code
df_z <- df |>
  mutate(across(
    c(price, volume, market_cap,
      sentiment_score, search_interest,
      daily_return, volatility_7d),
    ~ scale(.)[,1],
    .names = "{.col}_z"
  ))

df_z |>
  select(coin, ends_with("_z")) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = ends_with("_z"),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "z"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    variable = gsub("_z", "", variable),
    variable = recode(variable,
      price = "Price",
      volume = "Volume",
      market_cap = "Market Cap",
      sentiment_score = "Sentiment Score",
      search_interest = "Search Interest",
      daily_return = "Daily Return",
      volatility_7d = "7 Day Volatility"
    )
  ) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = coin, y = z, fill = coin)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.color = "#e6550d", alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 3,  linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
  facet_wrap(~ variable, scales = "free_y", ncol = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Outlier Detection Using Standardized Z-Scores",
    x = "Coin",
    y = "Z-Score"
  ) +
  theme_grey(base_size = 15) + theme(legend.position = "none")









Standardizing the variables makes it easier to compare their distributions. A few observations fall beyond ±3 standard deviations for Volume, Daily Return, and Seven Day Volatility. These points line up with periods of sharp price swings or heavy trading, which are typical features of cryptocurrency markets. Sentiment and Search Interest show occasional spikes during times of increased public attention. None of these observations indicate problems with data quality, so all values are kept in the dataset.
The final cleaned and imputed dataset used in results.qmd is saved in data/clean/.


Code
# Create the final cleaned dataset for exploration
# Use imputed sentiment and search interest
# Retain derived metrics as originally computed

df_final <- df_imputed |>
  transmute(
    date,
    coin,
    price,
    volume,
    market_cap,
    sentiment_score = sentiment_score_imp,
    search_interest = search_interest_imp,
    daily_return    = daily_return_imp,
    volatility_7d   = volatility_7d_imp
  )

# Save to clean data folder
write_csv(
  df_final,
  here("data", "clean", "crypto_final_clean.csv")
)

title: 3  Results
text:
3.1 Overview
This chapter explores how price movements, sentiment, and search attention evolve over time for Bitcoin and Ethereum. The analysis is descriptive and focuses on answering three questions:
The chapter begins by establishing baseline market behavior through price and volatility trends. It then examines sentiment as a behavioral indicator, exploring how online attitudes evolve alongside market movements and whether sentiment provides any leading signal for returns. The same structure is applied to search interest. Finally, the chapter compares how these behavioral signals relate to each asset’s return distribution.

title: 3  Results
text:
How do prices, sentiment, and public attention change over time?
How closely do sentiment and search interest track market volatility?
Do Bitcoin and Ethereum respond differently to behavioral signals?

title: 3  Results
section: 3.2 How Did Bitcoin and Ethereum Prices Move This Year?
text:
3.2 How Did Bitcoin and Ethereum Prices Move This Year?
Before examining behavioral signals, we establish how prices evolved. This baseline helps interpret the sentiment and search patterns that follow.


Code
ggplot(df, aes(x = date, y = price, color = coin)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_dollar()) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 1, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Price (USD)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.1: Both coins follow similar seasonal patterns, declining early in the year, rallying through summer, and pulling back in fall.





Bitcoin and Ethereum move through the year in similar waves. Both decline early, recover strongly in summer, and pull back again in fall. Bitcoin begins near $100,000, dips to the low $80,000s in spring, then rallies above $120,000 before softening. Ethereum follows the same pattern with larger percentage swings, falling from around $4,000 to below $2,000 early in the year before nearly doubling off its lows.
This parallel movement reflects how closely both markets respond to the same macroeconomic forces and investor sentiment. Neither coin stays stable for long.

title: 3  Results
text:
3.3 When Were Markets Most Volatile?
Price direction tells only part of the story. Volatility captures how much prices swing day to day. Higher volatility means larger and more frequent price changes.


Code
df_vol <- df |>
  mutate(daily_return = as.numeric(daily_return)) |>
  group_by(coin) |>
  mutate(
    abs_return = abs(daily_return),
    roll_vol = rollapply(abs_return, width = 14, FUN = mean,
                         fill = NA, align = "right")
  )

ggplot(df_vol, aes(x = date, y = roll_vol, color = coin)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 1, scales = "free_y") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent()) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Two-Week Rolling Volatility"
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.2: Volatility spikes in spring and fall for both coins, with Ethereum consistently showing larger swings than Bitcoin.





Both assets move through clear periods of calm and turbulence. Volatility rises in spring and again in fall, matching moments when markets reacted to shifting economic news. Ethereum has consistently higher volatility throughout the year. Bitcoin is steadier, with smaller and less frequent spikes. The midsummer volatility increase for both coins appears shortly after their price rebounds, showing that rallies can bring uncertainty alongside optimism.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.4 Does Online Sentiment Track Market Movements?
text:
3.4 Does Online Sentiment Track Market Movements?
Sentiment captures the tone of online discussions, positive values indicate optimism, negative values indicate concern, and values near zero reflect neutral attitudes. If sentiment moves with prices, it suggests that online mood reflects market conditions.


Code
ggplot(df, aes(x = date, y = sentiment_score, color = coin)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.5, linewidth = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 1.2, span = 0.15) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 1, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Sentiment Score"
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.3: Sentiment rises during the summer rally and falls during the spring and fall declines, following price cycles rather than leading them.





Sentiment for both coins moves within a fairly narrow band, with frequent short spikes. The broader trend rises through summer and dips in fall, aligning with price cycles. Ethereum shows slightly sharper swings, suggesting its online discussions respond more strongly to news. Overall, sentiment follows price movements rather than leading them, consistent with investors reacting to events as they unfold.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.5 Are Big Price Swings Accompanied by Extreme Sentiment?
text:
3.5 Are Big Price Swings Accompanied by Extreme Sentiment?
If sentiment relates to market activity, we would expect larger price moves to coincide with more emotional reactions. The violin plots below group days by the size of their price move and show how sentiment is distributed within each group.


Code
df_binned <- df |>
  mutate(
    return_bin = cut(
      abs(daily_return),
      breaks = c(0, 0.01, 0.03, 0.06, Inf),
      labels = c("Very Small\n(<1%)", "Small\n(1-3%)", "Medium\n(3-6%)", "Large\n(>6%)"),
      include.lowest = TRUE
    )
  ) |>
  filter(!is.na(return_bin))

ggplot(df_binned, aes(x = return_bin, y = sentiment_score, fill = coin)) +
  geom_violin(alpha = 0.7, trim = TRUE, color = "gray40", linewidth = 0.3) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Size of Daily Price Move",
    y = "Sentiment Score"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10)
  )








Figure 3.4: On calm days, sentiment clusters near neutral. On volatile days, sentiment spreads wider—some investors turn very optimistic while others turn very concerned.





For both coins, sentiment stays close to neutral when price moves are very small or small. As moves grow into the medium and large categories, sentiment spreads wider in both directions. Larger swings produce both more positive and more negative reactions rather than shifting sentiment uniformly one way. Ethereum shows a stronger increase in variation than Bitcoin, consistent with its more reactive market behavior.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.6 Can Yesterday’s Sentiment Predict Today’s Returns?
text:
3.6 Can Yesterday’s Sentiment Predict Today’s Returns?
The plots above show that sentiment moves alongside prices. But does sentiment provide any signal about what comes next? The scatterplots below compare yesterday’s sentiment with today’s return.


Code
df_lag <- df |>
  group_by(coin) |>
  mutate(
    sentiment_lag1 = lag(sentiment_score, 1),
    search_lag1 = lag(search_interest, 1)
  )

ggplot(df_lag, aes(x = sentiment_lag1, y = daily_return, color = coin)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.3, size = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 1.2, method = "loess") +
  facet_wrap(~ coin) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent()) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Sentiment (Previous Day)",
    y = "Daily Return"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.5: More positive sentiment tends to precede slightly higher returns the next day, though the relationship is weak. The effect is stronger for Ethereum.





Most points cluster near zero on both axes, typical sentiment changes do not correspond to large next-day moves. However, the smooth trends curve upward for each asset, suggesting that positive sentiment is often followed by slightly higher returns. Ethereum shows a stronger upward curve and wider spread of returns. The effect is modest and not predictive in a practical sense, but sentiment does appear more connected to Ethereum’s short-term movements than Bitcoin’s.


Code
df_bins <- df_lag |>
  mutate(
    sent_bin = cut(
      sentiment_lag1,
      breaks = quantile(sentiment_lag1, probs = c(0, .33, .66, 1), na.rm = TRUE),
      labels = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
      include.lowest = TRUE
    )
  )

sent_summary <- df_bins |>
  filter(!is.na(sent_bin)) |>
  group_by(coin, sent_bin) |>
  summarize(mean_return = mean(daily_return, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

ggplot(sent_summary, aes(x = sent_bin, y = mean_return, fill = coin)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), width = 0.7) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linewidth = 0.3, color = "gray50") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent()) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Previous-Day Sentiment Level",
    y = "Mean Next-Day Return",
    fill = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.6: Grouping days by sentiment level confirms the pattern: high sentiment precedes positive average returns for Ethereum, while Bitcoin shows little difference across groups.





For Bitcoin, returns hover near zero regardless of previous-day sentiment. Ethereum shows a clearer gradient: low sentiment precedes small losses on average, while high sentiment is followed by noticeably positive returns. This reinforces the finding that Ethereum responds more to shifts in sentiment than Bitcoin does.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.7 Does Search Interest Tell a Similar Story?
text:
3.7 Does Search Interest Tell a Similar Story?
Search interest captures how often people seek information about each coin, a proxy for public attention. The scale runs from 0 to 100, where 100 represents peak search activity during the year.


Code
ggplot(df, aes(x = date, y = search_interest, color = coin)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) +
  facet_wrap(~ coin, ncol = 1, scales = "free_y") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Search Interest (0-100)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.7: Search interest spikes during periods of high volatility and major news, with Bitcoin showing steadier attention and Ethereum experiencing sharper bursts.





Search interest moves in noticeable waves across the year. Peaks appear during periods of fast price changes or major news. Bitcoin shows strong attention early in the year and again in midsummer and late fall. Ethereum follows similar cycles with sharper bursts. Overall, search activity rises when markets are active or uncertain.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.8 Is Search Interest a Weaker Signal Than Sentiment?
text:
3.8 Is Search Interest a Weaker Signal Than Sentiment?
To test whether search interest provides a leading signal, we repeat the lagged analysis.


Code
ggplot(df_lag, aes(x = search_lag1, y = daily_return, color = coin)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.3, size = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 1.2, method = "loess") +
  facet_wrap(~ coin) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent()) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Search Interest (Previous Day)",
    y = "Daily Return"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    strip.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.8: Unlike sentiment, search interest shows almost no relationship with next-day returns. The trend lines are nearly flat for both coins.





Most points lie close to zero on both axes. The trend lines are nearly flat for Bitcoin and only gently sloped for Ethereum. Higher search interest does not consistently precede stronger price movements for either coin. Compared with sentiment, search interest provides an even weaker signal.


Code
df_bins2 <- df_lag |>
  mutate(
    search_bin = cut(
      search_lag1,
      breaks = quantile(search_lag1, probs = c(0, .33, .66, 1), na.rm = TRUE),
      labels = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
      include.lowest = TRUE
    )
  )

search_summary <- df_bins2 |>
  filter(!is.na(search_bin)) |>
  group_by(coin, search_bin) |>
  summarize(mean_return = mean(daily_return, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

ggplot(search_summary, aes(x = search_bin, y = mean_return, fill = coin)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), width = 0.7) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linewidth = 0.3, color = "gray50") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_percent()) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Previous-Day Search Level",
    y = "Mean Next-Day Return",
    fill = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.9: Average next-day returns show no consistent pattern across search levels, confirming that search interest is a poor leading indicator.





Bitcoin returns remain near zero across all search levels. Ethereum shows a small rise after medium search interest that disappears at high levels. Spikes in attention do not consistently translate into stronger price reactions. Search interest provides only weak and inconsistent signals compared with sentiment.

title: 3  Results
section: 3.9 Why Does Ethereum React More Strongly Than Bitcoin?
text:
3.9 Why Does Ethereum React More Strongly Than Bitcoin?
Throughout this analysis, Ethereum has shown larger responses to behavioral signals than Bitcoin. The return distributions below help explain why.


Code
ggplot(df, aes(x = daily_return, fill = coin)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.6, color = "gray30", linewidth = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = label_percent(), limits = c(-0.15, 0.15)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("BITCOIN" = "#3182bd", "ETHEREUM" = "#e6550d")) +
  labs(
    x = "Daily Return",
    y = "Density",
    fill = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )








Figure 3.10: Ethereum’s return distribution is wider with heavier tails, meaning it experiences larger daily swings in both directions. This greater volatility helps explain why behavioral signals relate more strongly to Ethereum’s movements.





Ethereum’s distribution is wider than Bitcoin’s with heavier tails on both sides. This confirms what the earlier analysis suggested: Ethereum experiences larger daily swings in both directions. Its sharper sentiment swings, higher volatility, and stronger response to lagged behavioral signals all trace back to this fundamental difference. Bitcoin’s tighter distribution reflects a more stable market that is less sensitive to shifts in online mood and attention.

title: 3  Results
text:
3.10 Summary
This exploratory analysis examined how sentiment and search interest relate to Bitcoin and Ethereum price movements. Three questions guided the investigation:
How do prices, sentiment, and public attention change over time? All three variables move in recognizable cycles. Prices decline early in the year, rally in summer, and pull back in fall. Sentiment and search interest follow these price cycles, rising during rallies and falling during declines.
How closely do sentiment and search interest track market volatility? Sentiment becomes more dispersed on high-volatility days, with both strongly positive and strongly negative readings appearing when price moves are large. Search interest also rises during volatile periods but does not show the same dispersion pattern. Sentiment appears more connected to the emotional character of market activity.
Do Bitcoin and Ethereum respond differently to behavioral signals? Yes. Ethereum consistently shows stronger reactions. It has wider sentiment swings, higher volatility, and a more dispersed return distribution. Previous-day sentiment shows a modest positive relationship with next-day returns for Ethereum but almost none for Bitcoin. Search interest provides weak signals for both coins. These differences suggest that Ethereum’s market is more sensitive to shifts in online attention and attitudes than Bitcoin’s is.

title: 4  Conclusion
text:
This exploratory analysis examined whether online sentiment and search interest reveal meaningful patterns in Bitcoin and Ethereum markets. The main takeaway is that behavioral signals move alongside prices and volatility but do not reliably lead them—sentiment and search interest reflect market mood rather than predict it. Among the two signals, sentiment shows a modest connection to next day returns for Ethereum, while search interest provides almost no useful signal for either coin. A consistent finding across all analyses is that Ethereum responds more strongly to behavioral indicators than Bitcoin does, likely because its market is smaller and more sensitive to shifts in attention and attitudes.
Several limitations constrain these findings. The dataset spans only one year due to free tier API restrictions, which may not capture longer term patterns or rare market regimes. Sentiment and search data required imputation for roughly 8% of days, and while the gaps appeared unrelated to price behavior, any imputation introduces uncertainty. The analysis is purely descriptive; no causal claims can be made about whether sentiment influences prices or simply reacts to them. Future work could extend the time window using paid data access, incorporate additional cryptocurrencies to test whether Ethereum’s heightened sensitivity generalizes to other altcoins, or apply time series modeling to more rigorously test lead lag relationships. The main lesson learned is that behavioral data in crypto markets is noisy and reactive—useful for understanding market mood in real time, but unlikely to offer a simple edge for anticipating what comes next.
